Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue STEM graduate programs and/or careers. Harris Stowe State College will boost retention of students entering the Biology program by adopting the innovative learning experience idea of using authentic research questions to teach foundational biology laboratory concepts. This project will infuse the Biology program with Biotechnology courses that will help prepare students for continuing education and to become part of the Biotechnology workforce hub in the St. Louis region. The BIO-BOOST project will focus on engagement and retention of early-stage (first and second-year) Biology students by creating interactions among students and faculty.

The goal of the BIO-BOOST targeted infusion project is to increase the retention of students entering the Biology program at Harris Stowe State College through engagement in biotechnology focused student-centered curriculum and projects based on authentic research experiences. The objectives of the BIO-BOOST project include: 1) implementation of a research-based Biotechnology curriculum; 2) creation of on-campus Biotechnology research experiences for freshmen; and 3) increased retention and networking of undergraduate students entering the Biology program. The project plans also include updating the Harris-Stowe Biology program with modern Biotechnology lab equipment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Success in STEM often begins early in a student’s undergraduate experience and students with improved access to quality opportunities can advance beyond their peers. Additionally, students that arrive at college with knowledge of the “unwritten rules” of success in science have an advantage over their peers. The primary goal of this grant was to restructure the freshmen biology experience at Harris-Stowe State University (HSSU) to help provide these opportunities and knowledge to our students. In this way, we can bring these students into the fold as well as the field. The primary aims of our grant were 1) to physically redesign a laboratory space and purchase equipment to support student research projects, 2) to redesign our freshmen curriculum to utilize this space and provide research experience and critical knowledge to our students, and 3) to investigate the effect of these changes on retention and students’ attitudes about science.

Over the course of the grant, a laboratory space was renovated and established as the first committed research space on campus. This space now houses all independent biology research projects while also serving as a space where research-focused, freshmen biology lab courses are taught. A unique and vigorous environment where freshmen students have access to modern molecular biology equipment and can observe their peers engaged in undergraduate research has emerged and helped to create a sustainable culture. Many students naturally continue from their freshmen biology lab courses into these independent research projects. Working closely with faculty on research projects early in their undergraduate career has helped to facilitate this process as well. As result, undergraduate research at HSSU is booming and additional expansion is expected.

In order to help students acquire the knowledge and experiences necessary for success in STEM, a new biotechnology course was created and freshman biology lab course was redesigned. In the biotechnology course, we teach students about the biotechnology landscape and help them learn the unwritten rules of STEM. In our freshman biology lab course, students learn a set of skills necessary for success in biology research and then are given an opportunity to create and engage in their own research project. Students research a topic of their interest, plan and conduct experiments, analyze and interpret results, and then present their findings. This process provides them their first research experience and can help to jumpstart their career in STEM. Several students presented their projects at national or regional conferences as well giving them experience in networking and exposure to other fields of research.

Previous studies have demonstrated the strength of Classroom Undergraduate Research Experiences (CUREs) in improving student engagement and helping students develop attitudes necessary for success in STEM. Improved student engagement from CUREs could also help to retain students in STEM. Retention of students that had taken the previous non-CURE biology lab course was compared with retention of students that had taken the course with the new curriculum and a 9.6% increase in retention was observed. In particular, we found a 300% in students that attended every class session. Further investigation revealed that students deeply enjoyed conducting independent experiments, working with model organisms, and investigating questions of their own design providing an important insight to the nature of their improved engagement. Students who took the course were more likely to want to conduct experiments to gain knowledge, felt more prepared to pursue additional STEM-related opportunities, and were more interested in applying to graduate school.

These results indicate that the approach described in this grant can help to provide students the early, high-quality experiences necessary for success in STEM. Students in the redesigned lab course have improved engagement and retention and have begun developing the attitudes and skills necessary to achieve lasting success. Providing these experiences can have a spillover effect and lay the groundwork for creating a successful research program as well. Faculty now have an established research space, equipment to support their research, and a vigorous pipeline of potential undergraduate researchers. The work described in this grant has set the stage for HSSU to advance as a research institution and continue to develop and offer research opportunities to its growing student population.
